at the time in which the rental reservation is made. Security deposits are due one week
prior to the event. Once the reservation is made and payment is made your event is guaranteed. Failure to pay
the fees prior to the event, will be deemed to voluntary cancellation of the reservation. Payments for the rental
fees must be made online through Town Square.
(e) Refund of Security Deposit. The security deposit will be refunded if the Clubhouse and its contents are not
damaged and are in accordance with these conditions and to the satisfaction of the clubhouse committee
member. Damage to the Clubhouse or its contents, or failure to comply with these conditions will result in
forfeiture of the security deposit. The ROA Member will be responsible and liable for any damage that exceeds
the amount of the security deposit.

Supplies: The ROA Member is responsible for bringing their own supplies for their event. Replacement trash
bags for outdoor cans and indoor cans can be found in the pantry. Should you use any of the supplies in the
kitchen they are to be cleaned and put back where found.

La Ventana Clubhouse Rental Rules, Regulations and Pool Rules 2



Clean Up: The ROA Member is fully responsible for removal of all trash and garbage from the inside of the
clubhouse, pavilion area and any other areas that may have been used during the event. Cleanup is to be done
the same day of the event. Failure to do so will result in forfeit of Security Deposit. All equipment, flowers,
caterer related items must be removed the same day of the event unless prearranged with the Clubhouse
Committee Member. Failure to do so may result in forfeit of security deposit.

Holidays: The clubhouse may not be reserved or rented on the following Holidays: Valentines Day, Easter,
Memorial Day, Labor Day, Thanksgiving Day, Christmas Day, or New Years Eve. The intent of this clause is to
permit usage for LaVentana Community Events, on these particular Holidays.

La Ventana Water Usage Report  Page 12 

La Ventana Water Conservation Guidelines 

• Follow HTGCD Alarm Stage Water Curtailments from baseline allocations. 
• Stage 1 – 10% Reduction (Voluntary, May – September) 

• Stage 2 – 20% Reduction  

• Stage 3 – 30% Reduction 

• Stage 4 – 40% Reduction 

• Follow La Ventana ROA Drought contingency plan 
• Stage 1 – Irrigation and outdoor water use limited to twice a week (Voluntary) 

• Additional requirements for residents in The Preserve Phase 3 (see 

supplemental DCCR’s) 
• Phase 1 - May thru Jun – Mandatory, twice a week – Irrigation and outdoor use 

• Phase 2 - Jul thru Sep –   Mandatory, once a week – Irrigation and outdoor use 

• Stage 2 & 3 – Irrigation and outdoor water use on 5-day cycle (per address schedule), 

midnight to 10am, and: 

• prohibits outdoor use for washing of Flatwork & Structures; 

• Flushing of gutters, dust control; and  

• Water leaks to be repaired asap & prohibition for any general waste of water. 

• Stage 4 

• Irrigation strictly prohibited, with exception for stressed Shade Trees (per 

HTGCD recommendation) 

• All outdoor water uses from Hose Bibs prohibited (car washing, pool filling, etc.), 

except for that required for watering animals. 

• Water leaks to be repaired asap & prohibition for any general waste of water. 

NOTE: - There are no restrictions on outdoor water usages from Rain Collection Tanks

documents.content:
now holds 
Certificate of Convenience and Necessity (CCN No. 12920)—which gives it the exclusive right to 
provide retail water utility service to the La Ventana neighborhood. SWL uses Professional 
General Management Services, Inc. (PGMS) as its water facility manager for the operating and 
administrative services. Both SWL and PGMS are owned by the same individual—Patric King. 
We are not practicably able to change water companies.  

Who Controls How Much Water We Can Use? 

Texas has 98 Groundwater Conservation Districts (GCD) located throughout the state to 
manage groundwater use. We are within the Hays-Trinity district (HTGCD), and they are 
authorized to establish groundwater consumption budgets for all non-exempt wells within their 
district. A non-exempt well is a well capable of producing more than 25,000 gallons of 
groundwater/day. These types of wells are subject to permitting and must comply with the 
district’s production fee schedule and orders. The La Ventana water allocation set by HTGCD is 
just under 40 million gallons per year (122 acre-feet), for all of our allowed 307 connections.. 
Note, that neither La Ventana nor any other neighborhood in the HTGCD has the ability or 
power to regulate, control, or enforce water consumption.  

During this summer’s severe drought, it was the HTGCD which was responsible for calling for an 
emergency stage (40% curtailment) district wide. Limiting groundwater use during drought is 
the responsibility of groundwater conservation districts. Permit holders can be required to have 
plans to reduce demand during drought, but enforcement of the required reductions is 
challenging. You may notice that a few other water companies in the area have called for less 
strict drought restrictions than HTGCD has. This is because some areas (e.g., Dripping Springs 
and West Austin) get some of their water from Lake Travis via the Lower Colorado River 
Authority.

Hi Mike-
 
I asked for the account to be split as the first possible option and unfortunately, our accounting
team could not accommodate in our current software. We responded to Cagle Pugh and told
them they would need to track the payments for the past due portion from Mr. Olivetti.
 
Perhaps Cagle Pugh can draft the payment plan and act on collection enforcement should the
owners fail to make timely payments. Should Mrs. Olivetti be able to present a divorce decree
that shows Mr. Olivetti is responsible for arrears - that helps her in court should he not pay.
Should Mr. Olivetti not pay the arrears – the enforcement would be through the HOA collection
attorney and her divorce attorney to help enforce.
 
My opinion – this is not the HOA’s problem. Mr. Olivetti needs to pay the back balance in full
and we are done. He can carry a loan or credit card balance to pay off the balance due to the
HOA – not La Ventana incur additional attorney fees to track his past due debt.

Annual Meeting Reminder
Wednesday, October 23rd
6:30pm~
La Ventana Clubhouse

The La Ventana Board of Directors Election & Annual Meeting is scheduled for Wednesday, October 23rd at 6:30PM to 
be held in the La Ventana Clubhouse. We are soliciting members who are in good standing and interested in running 
for the La Ventana Board of Directors to be please complete and submit the application by Tuesday, October 1st at 
5PM. The board application can be found in your PS Property Mgmt. HOA portal under email. There will be a "Meet 
the Candidates" session held on Wednesday, October 2nd at the La Ventana Clubhouse to allow members of the 
community an opportunity to meet and Q/A with candidates.

Please keep these dates on your calendar:

• Deadline to submit board application: Tuesday, October 1st at 5PM to amy@psprop.net

• Meet the Candidates session: Wednesday, October 2nd at 6:30PM, La Ventana Clubhouse

• Board of Directors Election & Annual Meeting: Wednesday, October 23rd at 6:30PM, La Ventana Clubhouse

Updates & Reminders Continued

documents.content:
My name is Amy Loughrey, and I am the new community association manager for La Ventana 
appointed by PS Property Management. I am excited to be a part of this community! I have been to 
La Ventana several times and have greatly admired the beautiful area. 

I am a native Austinite and the mother of two wonderful grown children, Jesse and  
Faith. My husband and I live in the SW Austin community known as Shady Hollow. I have been in 
community management for the past 8 years and specifically with PS Property Management since 
March of this year.  

Outside of working, I enjoy time with my family and trips to the Texas coast. I am an avid animal 
lover and have 3 dogs and 3 kitties. 

I look forward to interacting with you all in this wonderful community. I am here to serve you and 
enhance your neighborhood and experience with PS Property Management. So, please don't 
hesitate to reach out with any questions, comments, feedback, or your awesome ideas! 

Please reach me directly via: 

Phone: 512-779-3665 

Email: amy@psprop.net 

Billing: PS Property Management 

 P.O. Box 7079 

 Round Rock, TX 

 invoices@psprop.net 

 

 Thank you, 

Amy Loughrey, CMCA, AMS 

mailto:amy@psprop.net

4874‐3371‐3441v.6 53762‐1 10/13/2024 

RENTAL AND LEASING RULES 

Rental and Leasing Rules 

The  following  rules  are  adopted  by  the  La Ventan Ranch Owners  Association,  Inc.  (the  
“Association”) and shall apply to every owner (“Owner”) of a lot (“Lot”) in La Ventana ROA.  

Leasing Requirements. The rental or lease of any Lot must comply with the following rules: 

1. Minimum Lease Term. Any lease must be for an initial term of not less than ninety (90) 
days. The foregoing  leasing restriction shall not apply to an Owner who, following the 
sale of a Lot, leases the Lot back from the purchaser.

2. Entire Lot Leased. A Lot may be  leased only  in  its entirety; no fraction or portion of a 
Lot may be leased.

3. Lease to be in Writing. The lease must be in writing.

4. Rules to be Provided to Lessee. The Owner must provide the lessee with copies of the 
Declaration,   including   all   amendments,   and   all   rules,   regulations,   policies  
and procedures of the Association (the “Governing Documents”) as a condition of 

entering into the lease. The lease shall provide that the lessee and all occupants of the 
leased Lot are bound by and obligated to comply with the Governing Documents.

5. Registration.  An  Owner  who  wishes  to  lease  a  Lot  must  provide  a  completed 
registration document (the “Lease Notice Form”) to the Association at least ten (10) days 
before the commencement of any occupancy period. Any renewal agreement must also 
be provided to the Association.

6. Owner Responsible; Association Not Liable for Damages. The Owner of a leased Lot is 
liable to the Association for any expenses incurred by the Association in connection with 
enforcement of the Governing Documents against the Owner’s lessee. The Association is 
not liable to the Owner for any damages, including lost rents, suffered by the Owner in 
relation  to  the  Association’s  enforcement  of  the  Association’s  Governing  Documents 
against the Owner’s lessee.

documents.content:
which residents have asked lately.  

Where Do We Get Our Water? 

La Ventana currently has 265homes and receives all of its water from three (3) deep water 
wells drilled within our neighborhood. All three wells pull groundwater from the Cow Creek 
Formation within the Middle Trinity Aquifer—part of the Edwards-Trinity Aquifer. An aquifer is 
an underground layer of water-bearing, permeable rock, rock fractures, or unconsolidated 
materials. This aquifer is not small. The Trinity Aquifer system consumes some 21,308 square 
miles of subsurface and extends across much of central and northeastern Texas. It consists of 
three complexly interrelated aquifers-the Edwards-Trinity, the Edwards, and the Trinity 
aquifers. They are stratigraphically equivalent in part and are hydraulically connected in some 
places. Most wells in Hays County pull water from the Cow Creek Formation, shown in the 
illustration below. The current three wells have the following historically demonstrated 
maximum capacity:  Well #1: 70 gpm; Well #2: 50 gpm; Well #3: 30 gpm. However, the current 
capacity of our three wells (assuming all wells are performing at peak capacity) is 150 gpm.  The 
current actual capacity has been demonstrated in the 90-110 gpm range. 



 
 
 

 
 
  



Who Supplies Our Water? 

Texas has 4,642 community water systems (CWS), of which 1,820 are privately-owned and 
4,308 serve populations of 10,000 or fewer. La Ventana’s water needs are provided by such a 
privately-owned utility called Southwest Liquids, Inc. (SWL).  On February 13, 2017, the Texas 
Public Utility Commission (PUC) approved the sale and transfer of La Ventana, LLC, d/b/a/ La 
Ventana Water Company’s right to provide water to our neighborhood to SWL. SWL now holds 
Certificate of Convenience and Necessity (CCN No. 12920)—which gives it the exclusive right to 
provide retail water utility service to the La Ventana neighborhood. SWL uses Professional

while still allowing responsible, long-term rentals. Your support in amending the 
CCRs is crucial to keeping our community the peaceful, residential haven we all enjoy. Your participation in this 
process is exceptionally crucial, because 80% or more of the homeowners must vote for any amendments by the 
owners to be valid. Any less, and the effort fails. This is no small hurdle, because even in the most visible and 
consequential of national elections, voter turnout rarely tops 60% of eligible voters. Each property will get one vote. 
So, when the Board sends something to each of you about this important “Vrbo Amendment”, as we will call it, 
please know that if you don’t vote, it may be impossible for your Board to make the required amendment to the 
CCRs. Together, we can ensure that La Ventana Ranch remains a vibrant and thriving community for years to come.

documents.content:
Wednesday, October 2nd at 6:30PM, La Ventana Clubhouse

• Board of Directors Election & Annual Meeting: Wednesday, October 23rd at 6:30PM, La Ventana Clubhouse

Updates & Reminders Continued



As the La Ventana Ranch Owners’ Association (LVROA) continues to work diligently to preserve the beauty and 
harmony of our community, it has become evident that updates to the Codes, Covenants, and Restrictions (CCRs) 
are necessary. These changes aim to ensure that our neighborhood remains a desirable place to live, maintaining 
both its aesthetics and property values. As most of you are aware, the CCR’s are the tools used by your HOA Board 
to govern the use of a property in a community, and maintain consistency in property appearance, construction, 
maintenance, etc. These rules exist to protect property values and maintain consistency in the community. CC&Rs 
can include rules about, among other things: 

• Fences 
• Garbage cans Business openings
• Maintaining animals, livestock, etc.
• Unsightly or abandoned vehicles, trailers, etc., and
• New construction of homes or improvements.

By updating the CCRs, the Board is given the tools necessary to preserve the integrity of La Ventana Ranch, 
protecting property values and ensuring the long-term appeal of our neighborhood. These changes will help avoid 
situations where neglected properties or unapproved modifications negatively impact surrounding homes. Our CCRs 
have been in existence for many years and can be viewed on the website of PS Property Management, our new 
property management company. More information on these more global amendments will be forthcoming next year. 
In the meantime, there is one amendment that will be necessary on a more urgent basis to address unclear language 
within the CCR’s which may inadvertently allow Airbnb and Vrbo vacation home rentals to exist within the La Ventana 
community.

From: Amy Loughrey
To: mce58@protonmail.com
Subject: RE: La Ventana Ranch: Olivetti- 2516 La Ventana Pkwy [Firm-003884-000002]
Date: Tuesday, October 29, 2024 4:42:00 PM
Attachments: image003.png

image004.png
image005.png
image006.png
image007.png
image008.png

Hi Mike-
 
I asked for the account to be split as the first possible option and unfortunately, our accounting
team could not accommodate in our current software. We responded to Cagle Pugh and told
them they would need to track the payments for the past due portion from Mr. Olivetti.
 
Perhaps Cagle Pugh can draft the payment plan and act on collection enforcement should the
owners fail to make timely payments. Should Mrs. Olivetti be able to present a divorce decree
that shows Mr. Olivetti is responsible for arrears - that helps her in court should he not pay.
Should Mr. Olivetti not pay the arrears – the enforcement would be through the HOA collection
attorney and her divorce attorney to help enforce.
 
My opinion – this is not the HOA’s problem. Mr. Olivetti needs to pay the back balance in full
and we are done. He can carry a loan or credit card balance to pay off the balance due to the
HOA – not La Ventana incur additional attorney fees to track his past due debt.
 
Thank you,​​​​

Amy Loughrey
Community Manager

Good Afternoon!
 
I am following up on the email from the attorney below:
 
The only way for this to realistically work is for our office to draw up a payment plan for the
Olivettis to pay jointly. They both owned the property for several years. That debt is both of
theirs up until the time they divorced, and the house became her sole property. If the Olivettis
want to work out who pays what portion of the payment plan that’s between them.
 
Please let me know if the Board would like to respond to Mr. Garza’s communication prior to us
contacting the Olivett’s to arrange the joint payment plan.
 
Have a fantastic day!
 
Regards,
 
Dana Fenner

documents.content:
your project requires an application, please consult with any
member of the AC. It is better to contact them than to begin a project without approval! 
The application process is straightforward. Forms are available on the PS Management website under
Documents → Forms. Once you submit your application, the management company posts it, and then a
member of the AC will contact you to arrange a site visit. That visit to help clarify your plans and ensure they
align with the community’s standards. After the review, you’ll receive an email either granting approval or
asking for adjustments. If your project changes partway through construction, it’s important to resubmit
those changes for re-evaluation.

While the CCRs and Bylaws give the committee the authority to enforce compliance, your AC doesn’t see
itself as the neighborhood police. We are here to help and guide you with not only understanding the CCRs,
but the functionality of your project, and perhaps provide historical information.  The members view their role
as striking a balance between protecting individual homeowners’ visions and ensuring that those visions don’t
undermine the look or value of the community as a whole. The AC exists to prevent those conflicts and
maintain fairness. 

At the end of the day, the AC is one of those features of an HOA that may feel burdensome until you step
back and see the bigger picture. By following the process, you not only stay in compliance with the CCRs, but
you also contribute to keeping La Ventana the unique, harmonious, and beautiful place we all call home. 

La Ventana AC

Mona Jones- mkjones@me.com
Dave Blackwell- blave4152@att.net 
Miha Vindis- marquezvindis@gmail.com
Micheal Estinopal- Michael.estinopal@gmail.com

La Ventana Architectural Committee

documents.content:
4874‐3371‐3441v.6 53762‐1 10/13/2024 

RENTAL AND LEASING RULES 

Rental and Leasing Rules 

The  following  rules  are  adopted  by  the  La Ventan Ranch Owners  Association,  Inc.  (the  
“Association”) and shall apply to every owner (“Owner”) of a lot (“Lot”) in La Ventana ROA.  

Leasing Requirements. The rental or lease of any Lot must comply with the following rules: 

1. Minimum Lease Term. Any lease must be for an initial term of not less than ninety (90) 
days. The foregoing  leasing restriction shall not apply to an Owner who, following the 
sale of a Lot, leases the Lot back from the purchaser.

2. Entire Lot Leased. A Lot may be  leased only  in  its entirety; no fraction or portion of a 
Lot may be leased.

3. Lease to be in Writing. The lease must be in writing.

4. Rules to be Provided to Lessee. The Owner must provide the lessee with copies of the 
Declaration,   including   all   amendments,   and   all   rules,   regulations,   policies  
and procedures of the Association (the “Governing Documents”) as a condition of 

entering into the lease. The lease shall provide that the lessee and all occupants of the 
leased Lot are bound by and obligated to comply with the Governing Documents.

5. Registration.  An  Owner  who  wishes  to  lease  a  Lot  must  provide  a  completed 
registration document (the “Lease Notice Form”) to the Association at least ten (10) days 
before the commencement of any occupancy period. Any renewal agreement must also 
be provided to the Association.

6. Owner Responsible; Association Not Liable for Damages. The Owner of a leased Lot is 
liable to the Association for any expenses incurred by the Association in connection with 
enforcement of the Governing Documents against the Owner’s lessee. The Association is 
not liable to the Owner for any damages, including lost rents, suffered by the Owner in 
relation  to  the  Association’s  enforcement  of  the  Association’s  Governing  Documents 
against the Owner’s lessee.

address of each person who

b. Registration Fee. The Association may charge a registration  fee  that must be

submitted at the time of registration.

10. Fines. The following fines have been established by the Board of Directors pursuant to

the  enforcement  authority  set  forth  in  the Declaration. Owners  violating  the  Leasing

Rules,  including a violation of  the minimum  lease  term, may be  fined  the amounts set

forth below:

Violation  Fine Amount 

Failure to Register  
Initial Fine: $1000 
After 15 Days: $200 per week  

Unauthorized Rental   $2,500 per week  

All Other Violations  
Initial Fine: $1000 
Continuing Violation: $200 per week  

NOTE:  Short‐term  rental  activity  prohibited  under  these  rules  will  be 

considered a continuing violation if the Lot continues to be advertised for lease 

periods shorter than the minimum term set forth herein. Accordingly, the daily 

fine amount will apply  to  the entire period of  time until all  rental activity,  to 

include  both  leasing  and  advertising  for  terms  less  than  ninety  (90)  days, 

ceases.  

11. Existing Leases. All leasing arrangements in existence on or before the date these rules

are  recorded must be  registered with  the Association within ninety  (90) days of  these

rules becoming effective.



4874‐3371‐3441v.6 53762‐1 10/13/2024 

12. Miscellaneous. Any capitalized terms used and not otherwise defined herein shall have

the meanings set forth in the Declaration.

7. Use of Community Amenities. An Owner who does not occupy a home in La Ventana 
ROA is  not  entitled  to  use  the  community  amenities  if  the  Lot  is  used  for  rental  
purposes. Although an Owner has a general right to delegate to a lessee the Owner’s 

right to use common area amenities, the Association may condition the lessee’s use on 

the Owner’s compliance with procedures to confirm ownership and verify tenancy.

8. Violation  Constitutes  Default.  Failure  by  the  lessee  or  the  lessee’s  invitees  to  comply 
with  the Governing Documents will be deemed  to be a default under  the  lease. When



4874‐3371‐3441v.6 53762‐1 10/13/2024 

the Association notifies  an Owner  of  such Owner’s  lessee’s violation,  the Owner will 

promptly  obtain  the Owner’s  lessee’s  compliance  or  exercise  the Owner’s  rights  as  a 

landlord for lessee’s breach of lease. If the lessee’s violation continues or is repeated, and 

if  the  Owner  is  unable,  unwilling,  or  unavailable  to  obtain  the  Owner’s  lessee’s 

compliance,  then  the Association has  the power and right  to pursue  the remedies of a 

landlord  for  the  default,  including  eviction  of  the  lessee,  subject  to  the  terms  of  the 

Declaration.  

9. Registration  Procedures.  The  following  registration  requirements  have  been

established by  the Association pursuant  to  the  enforcement  authority  set  forth  in  the

Declaration.

a. Registration Required. An Owner  seeking  to  lease  a Lot must  provide  the

name, mailing address, phone number, and e‐mail address of each person who

will  reside  at  a  Lot  under  a  lease,  along  with  the  start/end  dates,  and  any

required fees and documentation, to the Association prior to the commencement

Ballot 

As discussed at the most recent la Ventana board meeting, the LVROA Board of Directors is requesting your 
participation in voting to amend Declaration Article 3.41. In order to address the presence of weekend rentals 

of homes within our neighborhood, we are requesting your review and consideration to amend the current 

Declaration to help provide a concise rental policy and to discourage VRBO rentals. The amended CCR section 
would provide a defined length of time any single lot may be utilized for both short-term rentals (defined as six 

months to one year) and long-term rental (over one year). The Board feels that the new definition will help 

prevent the utilization of homes in la Ventana through Airbnb, VRBO, Vacasa, and other similar home rental 

companies. No rentals of less than six months will be allowed if this amendment passes. The current La Ventana 

Declaration as well as the Texas Property Code § 209.0041 require that "a declaration may be amended only by 

a vote of 67 percent of the total votes allocated to property owners. Therefore, it is important that everybody 

vote and be heard on this issue. Please remind your friends and neighbors to also vote. 

The La Ventana Board of Directors strongly urges you to vote for Option #1, in support of the Proposed 
Amendment (in green) below. 

Cyrrent Section 3.41: 

3.41 Rentals. Nothing in this Declaration shall prevent the rental of an entire Lot and-the Improvements 
thereon by the Owner thereof for residential purposes, on either a short or long-term basis. In such event, 
both Owner and tenant shall be responsible for compliance with this Declaration and all La Ventana Rules. 
No Lot, including Improvements on a Lot, may be leased to more than four (4) adults at any one time. 

3.41 Rentals.

La Ventana Ranch Owners’ Association, Inc.
c/o PS. Property Management 
P.O. Box 7079, Round Rock, TX 78683 
(512) 251– 6122 | info@psprop.net
Protect La Ventana – Vote to Prohibit Short-Term Rentals!
March 18, 2025
Dear Neighbors,
Our serene La Ventana community is at risk of experiencing a proliferation of weekend rental properties, turning homes into weekend “party houses” through Airbnb, VRBO, and similar platforms. To maintain the peace, security, and character of our neighborhood (not to mention the property values), the La Ventana HOA Board is proposing an important amendment to our Covenants, Conditions, and Restrictions (CCRs).
Why This Matters:
✅ Preserve Neighborhood Peace & Safety – Short-term rentals bring a revolving door of strangers, increasing noise, parking issues, and security concerns.
✅ Protect Property Values – Studies show that neighborhoods with excessive short-term rentals often see declining home values.
✅ Maintain Our Community’s Integrity – We are a residential community, not a vacation rental destination. Let’s keep La Ventana a place where neighbors know and trust each other.
✅ Prevent Amenity Misuse – Short-term guests have access to our community’s gated entrance, pool, trails, and other amenities—without the vested interest of a homeowner.
A ballot will be sent to you via email and the voting will start in April. To pass this amendment, we need 67% of homeowners to vote in favor. This is not easy to accomplish and if we do not reach that benchmark, the proposed amendment will fail. Your vote is crucial!
1 Vote per Lot (owners with multiple lots are weighted, no multiple votes per homeowner)
✅ Vote YES to amend Article 3.41 and prohibit rentals of less than six months. Let’s protect La Ventana together!
Questions? Contact PS Property Management at info@psprop.net.
La Ventana HOA Board of Directors

documents.content:
now holds 
Certificate of Convenience and Necessity (CCN No. 12920)—which gives it the exclusive right to 
provide retail water utility service to the La Ventana neighborhood. SWL uses Professional 
General Management Services, Inc. (PGMS) as its water facility manager for the operating and 
administrative services. Both SWL and PGMS are owned by the same individual—Patric King. 
We are not practicably able to change water companies.  

Who Controls How Much Water We Can Use? 

Texas has 98 Groundwater Conservation Districts (GCD) located throughout the state to 
manage groundwater use. We are within the Hays-Trinity district (HTGCD), and they are 
authorized to establish groundwater consumption budgets for all non-exempt wells within their 
district. A non-exempt well is a well capable of producing more than 25,000 gallons of 
groundwater/day. These types of wells are subject to permitting and must comply with the 
district’s production fee schedule and orders. The La Ventana water allocation set by HTGCD is 
just under 40 million gallons per year (122 acre-feet), for all of our allowed 307 connections.. 
Note, that neither La Ventana nor any other neighborhood in the HTGCD has the ability or 
power to regulate, control, or enforce water consumption.  

During this summer’s severe drought, it was the HTGCD which was responsible for calling for an 
emergency stage (40% curtailment) district wide. Limiting groundwater use during drought is 
the responsibility of groundwater conservation districts. Permit holders can be required to have 
plans to reduce demand during drought, but enforcement of the required reductions is 
challenging. You may notice that a few other water companies in the area have called for less 
strict drought restrictions than HTGCD has. This is because some areas (e.g., Dripping Springs 
and West Austin) get some of their water from Lake Travis via the Lower Colorado River 
Authority.

documents.content:
which residents have asked lately.  

Where Do We Get Our Water? 

La Ventana currently has 265homes and receives all of its water from three (3) deep water 
wells drilled within our neighborhood. All three wells pull groundwater from the Cow Creek 
Formation within the Middle Trinity Aquifer—part of the Edwards-Trinity Aquifer. An aquifer is 
an underground layer of water-bearing, permeable rock, rock fractures, or unconsolidated 
materials. This aquifer is not small. The Trinity Aquifer system consumes some 21,308 square 
miles of subsurface and extends across much of central and northeastern Texas. It consists of 
three complexly interrelated aquifers-the Edwards-Trinity, the Edwards, and the Trinity 
aquifers. They are stratigraphically equivalent in part and are hydraulically connected in some 
places. Most wells in Hays County pull water from the Cow Creek Formation, shown in the 
illustration below. The current three wells have the following historically demonstrated 
maximum capacity:  Well #1: 70 gpm; Well #2: 50 gpm; Well #3: 30 gpm. However, the current 
capacity of our three wells (assuming all wells are performing at peak capacity) is 150 gpm.  The 
current actual capacity has been demonstrated in the 90-110 gpm range. 



 
 
 

 
 
  



Who Supplies Our Water? 

Texas has 4,642 community water systems (CWS), of which 1,820 are privately-owned and 
4,308 serve populations of 10,000 or fewer. La Ventana’s water needs are provided by such a 
privately-owned utility called Southwest Liquids, Inc. (SWL).  On February 13, 2017, the Texas 
Public Utility Commission (PUC) approved the sale and transfer of La Ventana, LLC, d/b/a/ La 
Ventana Water Company’s right to provide water to our neighborhood to SWL. SWL now holds 
Certificate of Convenience and Necessity (CCN No. 12920)—which gives it the exclusive right to 
provide retail water utility service to the La Ventana neighborhood. SWL uses Professional

Dear Property Owners,

The La Ventana ROA Board of Directors approved the 2025 Annual Budget at a meeting of the board on December 18, 2024. The 2025 Annual Budget that was approved has a stated increase in the monthly assessment for each lot to $133 per month. 

The LVROA assessment increase will go into effect on February 1, 2025. Please adjust any auto draft payments to reflect the updated amount due. The assessment is considered late after the 31st of each month. Please make sure your payments reflect the correct amount and due date to avoid any late fee penalties.

Payments can be made online via your homeowner portal by login at https://owner.psprop.net/login. Online payments can be made for a fee utilizing a credit card or a single ACH e-check payment. To avoid a fee, you would need to set up recurring ACH e-check payments. You may also choose to make payments via US mail by mailing payments to: PS Property Management, 1490 Rusk Road, Ste. 301, Round Rock, TX 78665. Owners may submit payments in person at our South Austin location: 8701 Menchaca Road, Bldg. 2, Ste. 203, Austin, TX 78748.

documents.content:
UNDERSTANDING THE WATER ISSUES AFFECTING LA VENTANA 
 

Gary L. Wickert 
 
It is often said that rumors are more exciting than the truth. That certainly seemed to be the 
case this spring as my wife and I looked for a home in central Texas in order to be closer to two 
of our children and several grandchildren. La Ventana was high on our list, but we had heard 
from more than one source that the water supply to the neighborhood was rationed, very 
expensive, and even running dry. I learned long ago never to rely on the tom-toms beating on 
the street; so, I investigated. What I found convinced me that this was the place for us to live, 
and we moved last July, at the height of the 24th driest summer in the past 129 years. Having 
come from rural Wisconsin—a state boasting 15,000+ inland natural lakes and bordering 21% of 
the Earth’s surface fresh water—we were strangers to water issues. Thankfully, we are most 
fortunate that our neighborhood Water Committee members resemble a Who’s Who of 
experts on the subject. They answered a lot of my questions and are available to answer yours 
as well.  
 
The first thing I learned was that neither La Ventana nor the wells from which we get our fresh 
water was going to run out of water. The issues we face have more to do with maintaining our 
water system infrastructure and compelling our water utility to comply with orders previously 
issued by the state of Texas. A thorough dissertation on water utilities and hydrogeology would 
be neither practical nor helpful here. La Ventana is home to some of the most experienced 
geologists and hydrogeologists I have ever known, and the La Ventana Ranch Owners’ 
Association (LVROA) board felt it would be helpful if we would publicly answer several 
questions which residents have asked lately.  

Where Do We Get Our Water? 

La Ventana currently has 265homes and receives all of its water from three (3) deep water 
wells drilled within our neighborhood.

documents.content:
now holds 
Certificate of Convenience and Necessity (CCN No. 12920)—which gives it the exclusive right to 
provide retail water utility service to the La Ventana neighborhood. SWL uses Professional 
General Management Services, Inc. (PGMS) as its water facility manager for the operating and 
administrative services. Both SWL and PGMS are owned by the same individual—Patric King. 
We are not practicably able to change water companies.  

Who Controls How Much Water We Can Use? 

Texas has 98 Groundwater Conservation Districts (GCD) located throughout the state to 
manage groundwater use. We are within the Hays-Trinity district (HTGCD), and they are 
authorized to establish groundwater consumption budgets for all non-exempt wells within their 
district. A non-exempt well is a well capable of producing more than 25,000 gallons of 
groundwater/day. These types of wells are subject to permitting and must comply with the 
district’s production fee schedule and orders. The La Ventana water allocation set by HTGCD is 
just under 40 million gallons per year (122 acre-feet), for all of our allowed 307 connections.. 
Note, that neither La Ventana nor any other neighborhood in the HTGCD has the ability or 
power to regulate, control, or enforce water consumption.  

During this summer’s severe drought, it was the HTGCD which was responsible for calling for an 
emergency stage (40% curtailment) district wide. Limiting groundwater use during drought is 
the responsibility of groundwater conservation districts. Permit holders can be required to have 
plans to reduce demand during drought, but enforcement of the required reductions is 
challenging. You may notice that a few other water companies in the area have called for less 
strict drought restrictions than HTGCD has. This is because some areas (e.g., Dripping Springs 
and West Austin) get some of their water from Lake Travis via the Lower Colorado River 
Authority.

documents.content:
much is currently happening in this claim right now, but we have a mediation 
scheduled for next March and hope to work things out then.  

What About Residents Who Consume Large Amounts of Water? 

Good conservation measures mean that all residents should comply with reasonable 
restrictions.  Neither La Ventana nor its Board have any power or authority to compel LVROA 
residents to comply with recommended water restrictions or comply with drought mandates. In 
the PUC orders mentioned above, SWL was required to communicate with “high consuming” 
customers to encourage more reasonable consumption practices. They had not been doing this. 
More recently, “high consuming” residents have been receiving letters advising that if they do 
not cut their consumption, SWL would install a meter flow restrictor on their water meter.  
  



Should La Ventana Purchase Southwest Liquids?  

There has been some discussion of La Ventana purchasing SWL and operating it ourselves. This 
possibility is less expensive than it sounds but is fraught with an entirely new set of problems, 
expenses, and responsibilities. Without making public information and ideas which may give 
SWL a negotiating advantage should we ever decide to go this route, suffice it to say that there 
is general consensus on the Board and among our residents that we should not pursue this 
strategy. In many ways, if we operated our own water utility, we might be able to more adroitly 
handle many of the maintenance, water supply, water quality, and infrastructure concerns. But 
we are not in the business of owning and operating utilities—we are a residential 
neighborhood. Purchasing SWL costs money and your board is simultaneously committed to 
the excellence of our services, amenities, and infrastructure, and saving money.  

We should also be aware that there is a good possibility that SWL sells the water company to 
another Investor-Owned Utility such as Aqua Texas.

Perhaps Cagle Pugh can draft the payment plan and act on collection enforcement should the

My opinion – this is not the HOA’s problem. Mr. Olivetti needs to pay the back balance in full

La Ventana Water Usage Report  Page 12 

La Ventana Water Conservation Guidelines 

• Follow HTGCD Alarm Stage Water Curtailments from baseline allocations. 
• Stage 1 – 10% Reduction (Voluntary, May – September) 

• Stage 2 – 20% Reduction  

• Stage 3 – 30% Reduction 

• Stage 4 – 40% Reduction 

• Follow La Ventana ROA Drought contingency plan 
• Stage 1 – Irrigation and outdoor water use limited to twice a week (Voluntary) 

• Additional requirements for residents in The Preserve Phase 3 (see 

supplemental DCCR’s) 
• Phase 1 - May thru Jun – Mandatory, twice a week – Irrigation and outdoor use 

• Phase 2 - Jul thru Sep –   Mandatory, once a week – Irrigation and outdoor use 

• Stage 2 & 3 – Irrigation and outdoor water use on 5-day cycle (per address schedule), 

midnight to 10am, and: 

• prohibits outdoor use for washing of Flatwork & Structures; 

• Flushing of gutters, dust control; and  

• Water leaks to be repaired asap & prohibition for any general waste of water. 

• Stage 4 

• Irrigation strictly prohibited, with exception for stressed Shade Trees (per 

HTGCD recommendation) 

• All outdoor water uses from Hose Bibs prohibited (car washing, pool filling, etc.), 

except for that required for watering animals. 

• Water leaks to be repaired asap & prohibition for any general waste of water. 

NOTE: - There are no restrictions on outdoor water usages from Rain Collection Tanks

documents.content:
4874‐3371‐3441v.6 53762‐1 10/13/2024 

RENTAL AND LEASING RULES 

Rental and Leasing Rules 

The  following  rules  are  adopted  by  the  La Ventan Ranch Owners  Association,  Inc.  (the  
“Association”) and shall apply to every owner (“Owner”) of a lot (“Lot”) in La Ventana ROA.  

Leasing Requirements. The rental or lease of any Lot must comply with the following rules: 

1. Minimum Lease Term. Any lease must be for an initial term of not less than ninety (90) 
days. The foregoing  leasing restriction shall not apply to an Owner who, following the 
sale of a Lot, leases the Lot back from the purchaser.

2. Entire Lot Leased. A Lot may be  leased only  in  its entirety; no fraction or portion of a 
Lot may be leased.

3. Lease to be in Writing. The lease must be in writing.

4. Rules to be Provided to Lessee. The Owner must provide the lessee with copies of the 
Declaration,   including   all   amendments,   and   all   rules,   regulations,   policies  
and procedures of the Association (the “Governing Documents”) as a condition of 

entering into the lease. The lease shall provide that the lessee and all occupants of the 
leased Lot are bound by and obligated to comply with the Governing Documents.

5. Registration.  An  Owner  who  wishes  to  lease  a  Lot  must  provide  a  completed 
registration document (the “Lease Notice Form”) to the Association at least ten (10) days 
before the commencement of any occupancy period. Any renewal agreement must also 
be provided to the Association.

6. Owner Responsible; Association Not Liable for Damages. The Owner of a leased Lot is 
liable to the Association for any expenses incurred by the Association in connection with 
enforcement of the Governing Documents against the Owner’s lessee. The Association is 
not liable to the Owner for any damages, including lost rents, suffered by the Owner in 
relation  to  the  Association’s  enforcement  of  the  Association’s  Governing  Documents 
against the Owner’s lessee.

From: Amy Loughrey
To: mce58@protonmail.com
Subject: RE: La Ventana Ranch: Olivetti- 2516 La Ventana Pkwy [Firm-003884-000002]
Date: Tuesday, October 29, 2024 4:42:00 PM
Attachments: image003.png

image004.png
image005.png
image006.png
image007.png
image008.png

Hi Mike-
 
I asked for the account to be split as the first possible option and unfortunately, our accounting
team could not accommodate in our current software. We responded to Cagle Pugh and told
them they would need to track the payments for the past due portion from Mr. Olivetti.
 
Perhaps Cagle Pugh can draft the payment plan and act on collection enforcement should the
owners fail to make timely payments. Should Mrs. Olivetti be able to present a divorce decree
that shows Mr. Olivetti is responsible for arrears - that helps her in court should he not pay.
Should Mr. Olivetti not pay the arrears – the enforcement would be through the HOA collection
attorney and her divorce attorney to help enforce.
 
My opinion – this is not the HOA’s problem. Mr. Olivetti needs to pay the back balance in full
and we are done. He can carry a loan or credit card balance to pay off the balance due to the
HOA – not La Ventana incur additional attorney fees to track his past due debt.
 
Thank you,​​​​

Amy Loughrey
Community Manager

(512) 399‑4616 (A.I. Texting Assistant)
 www.psprop.net

Hi Mike!
 
Do you think the recommendation below from Cagle Pugh will work for LVR and the
Olivetti’s? Seems reasonable to me…Or request that Mr. Olivetti pay the back balance in
full because we do not want to be in the payment plan business. Perhaps there is a good
relationship here to work with on this issue and you can trust everyone to pay the back
balance.
 
Thank you,​​​​

Amy Loughrey
Community Manager

From: Dana Fenner <dana.fenner@caglepugh.com> 
Sent: Tuesday, November 5, 2024 3:27 PM
To: Amy Loughrey <amy@psprop.net>
Cc: Terry Zilem <terry@psprop.net>; Greg Garza <greg.garza@caglepugh.com>
Subject: RE: La Ventana Ranch: Olivetti- 2516 La Ventana Pkwy [Firm-003884-000002]
 
Good Afternoon!
 
I am following up on the email from the attorney below:
 
The only way for this to realistically work is for our office to draw up a payment plan for the
Olivettis to pay jointly. They both owned the property for several years. That debt is both of
theirs up until the time they divorced, and the house became her sole property. If the Olivettis
want to work out who pays what portion of the payment plan that’s between them.
 
Please let me know if the Board would like to respond to Mr. Garza’s communication prior to us
contacting the Olivett’s to arrange the joint payment plan.
 
Have a fantastic day!
 
Regards,
 
Dana Fenner
Paralegal
